elements.content: Four novel high-dimensional metal–organic rotaxane frameworks (MORFs) were successfully fabricated by cucurbit[6]­uril-based pseudorotaxanes ([PR43]) and rigid carboxylate ligands by adjusting the synthesis temperature and the length of ligands. Compound 1 represents a three periodic 2-fold interpenetrating dia network based on a binuclear {Cd2Cl4O4} second building unit (SBU). 2 and 3 are isostructural pcu networks constructed by binuclear and trinuclear cadmium clusters, respectively, while compound 4 is a two-dimensional layered network with a large grid 44.3 × 19.8 Å2. Furthermore, their fluorescent properties in different solvents are investigated.
elements.clean_text: Four novel high-dimensional metal-organic rotaxane frameworks (MORFs) were successfully fabricated by cucurbit[6]uril-based pseudorotaxanes ([PR43]) and rigid carboxylate ligands by adjusting the synthesis temperature and the length of ligands. Compound 1 represents a three periodic 2-fold interpenetrating dia network based on a binuclear {Cd2Cl4O4} second building unit (SBU). 2 and 3 are isostructural pcu networks constructed by binuclear and trinuclear cadmium clusters, respectively, while compound 4 is a two-dimensional layered network with a large grid 44.3 × 19.8 Å2. Furthermore, their fluorescent properties in different solvents are investigated.

elements.content: Four novel high-dimensional metal−organic rotaxane frameworks (MORFs) were fabricated by the self-assembly of CB[6]-based pseudorotaxanes [PR43]2+·2­[NO3]−, two rigid length varied carboxylate ligands (terephthalic acid (H2BDC) and 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (H2BPDC)), and suitable metal ions under hydrothermal mixed solvents. It is shown that the topologies of aimed MORFs can be tuned by the length of ligands as well as reaction temperature.
elements.clean_text: Four novel high-dimensional metal-organic rotaxane frameworks (MORFs) were fabricated by the self-assembly of CB[6]-based pseudorotaxanes [PR43]2+⋅2[NO3]-, two rigid length varied carboxylate ligands (terephthalic acid (H2BDC) and 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (H2BPDC)), and suitable metal ions under hydrothermal mixed solvents. It is shown that the topologies of aimed MORFs can be tuned by the length of ligands as well as reaction temperature.

elements.content: Design and synthesis of supramolecular architectures with desired structures, properties, and functions have attracted increasing attention in recent years. Currently, using supramolecular building blocks (SBBs) to construct metal–organic rotaxane frameworks (MORFs) has given rise to significant interest. Thanks to the constant efforts of the chemists, some achievements have been made in this area. For example, a series of coordination polymers with rotaxane linkers have been prepared and characterized by Loeb and co-workers. Moreover, the prosperities of some metal–organic rotaxane frameworks have been prepared in the past decade. To date, metal organic rotaxane frameworks containing macrocyclic molecules, especially with high dimensionalities, have rarely been reported. So, it remains a challenge for chemists to design and synthesize metal organic rotaxane frameworks in a controlled way.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Design and synthesis of supramolecular architectures with desired structures, properties, and functions have attracted increasing attention in recent years. Currently, using supramolecular building blocks (SBBs) to construct metal-organic rotaxane frameworks (MORFs) has given rise to significant interest. Thanks to the constant efforts of the chemists, some achievements have been made in this area. For example, a series of coordination polymers with rotaxane linkers have been prepared and characterized by Loeb and co-workers. Moreover, the prosperities of some metal-organic rotaxane frameworks have been prepared in the past decade. To date, metal organic rotaxane frameworks containing macrocyclic molecules, especially with high dimensionalities, have rarely been reported. So, it remains a challenge for chemists to design and synthesize metal organic rotaxane frameworks in a controlled way.

elements.content: Cucurbit­[n]­urils (CB­[n]­s), a class of rigid macrocyclic hosts with a rigid hydrophobic cavity and two identical carbonyl fringed portals, have attracted wide research interest in supramolecular chemistry. Over the past decade, the CB[6] has been widely studied in supramolecular chemistry and coordination chemistry. Since the first example of coordination polyrotaxanes that used [2]­pseudorotaxanes as linkers was prepared by Kim, only a few three-dimensional (3D) MORFs have been obtained to date, and most of them are based on single transition metal ions or lanthonide ions. Kim and others’ work shows that the utility of CB[6]-based pseudorotaxanes as building blocks for supra-architectures is an effective strategy to build MORFs even though the self-assembly process is largely affected by the nature of cucurbit[6]­uril. We therefore decided to modify our approach by using mixed ligands including rigid pseudorotaxanes and carboxylate ligands to fabricate novel high-dimensional CB[6] contained metal–organic rotaxane frameworks. On the other hand, the self-assembly process of some CB[6]-based molecular necklaces is sensitive to temperature as indicated by Kim. Bearing these in mind, we tried to study the temperature effect as well as the length of ligands on fabricating MORFs. Herein, we report four new MORFs assembled by CB[6]-based pseudorotaxanes [PR43]2+·2­[NO3]−, carboxylate ligands with different lengths (terephthalic acid (H2BDC) and 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (H2BPDC)) and suitable metals in mixed solvents and discuss the temperature effect for the obtained MORFs. Our research not only demonstrates for first time the important role of reaction temperature on synthesizing multinuclear-based MORFs but also presents a new family of the isoreticular MORFs containing CB[6].
elements.clean_text: Cucurbit[n]urils (CB[n]s), a class of rigid macrocyclic hosts with a rigid hydrophobic cavity and two identical carbonyl fringed portals, have attracted wide research interest in supramolecular chemistry. Over the past decade, the CB[6] has been widely studied in supramolecular chemistry and coordination chemistry. Since the first example of coordination polyrotaxanes that used [2]pseudorotaxanes as linkers was prepared by Kim, only a few three-dimensional (3D) MORFs have been obtained to date, and most of them are based on single transition metal ions or lanthonide ions. Kim and others' work shows that the utility of CB[6]-based pseudorotaxanes as building blocks for supra-architectures is an effective strategy to build MORFs even though the self-assembly process is largely affected by the nature of cucurbit[6]uril. We therefore decided to modify our approach by using mixed ligands including rigid pseudorotaxanes and carboxylate ligands to fabricate novel high-dimensional CB[6] contained metal-organic rotaxane frameworks. On the other hand, the self-assembly process of some CB[6]-based molecular necklaces is sensitive to temperature as indicated by Kim. Bearing these in mind, we tried to study the temperature effect as well as the length of ligands on fabricating MORFs. Herein, we report four new MORFs assembled by CB[6]-based pseudorotaxanes [PR43]2+⋅2[NO3]-, carboxylate ligands with different lengths (terephthalic acid (H2BDC) and 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (H2BPDC)) and suitable metals in mixed solvents and discuss the temperature effect for the obtained MORFs. Our research not only demonstrates for first time the important role of reaction temperature on synthesizing multinuclear-based MORFs but also presents a new family of the isoreticular MORFs containing CB[6].

elements.content: [PR43]2+·2­[NO3]− and CB[6] were synthesized according to refs . Other purchased chemicals were used without further purification. The IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a PerkinElmer TG-7 analyzer over the temperature 50–800 °C in a nitrogen-gas atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. Solid-state luminescent spectra were measured on a Cary Eclipse spectrofluorometer (Varian) equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were recorded on a Rigaku/Dmax 2200 pc diffractometer with Cu-Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation in the range 5–50°. X-ray diffraction data collection of the compounds was performed using a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. All absorption corrections were performed by using the SADABS program. Crystal data and structure refinement parameters for 1–4 are summarized in . CCDC: 1 (1060912), 2 (1060913), 3 (1060914), and 4 (1060915). Relevant crystal data can be obtained free of charge via http://www.ccdc.cam.atc.uk/conts/retrieving.html, or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; or e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Measurements

[PR43]2+⋅2[NO3]- and CB[6] were synthesized according to refs . Other purchased chemicals were used without further purification. The IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a PerkinElmer TG-7 analyzer over the temperature 50-800 °C in a nitrogen-gas atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Solid-state luminescent spectra were measured on a Cary Eclipse spectrofluorometer (Varian) equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were recorded on a Rigaku/Dmax 2200 pc diffractometer with Cu-Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation in the range 5-50°. X-ray diffraction data collection of the compounds was performed using a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. All absorption corrections were performed by using the SADABS program. Crystal data and structure refinement parameters for 1-4 are summarized in . CCDC: 1 (1060912), 2 (1060913), 3 (1060914), and 4 (1060915). Relevant crystal data can be obtained free of charge via http://www.ccdc.cam.atc.uk/conts/retrieving.html, or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; or e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.

A mixture of CdCl2·8H2O (16.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), [PR43]2+·2­[NO3]− (80 mg, 0.05 mmol), H2BDC (8.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), and 4 mL of H2O/DMF (3:1) was stirred for 30 min, and then transferred and sealed in a 18 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which is heated at 100 °C for 72 h. Block colorless crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained, washed with distilled water, and dried in air. Yield: 40.6% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C120H142Cd4Cl8N56O39. (%): C 38.68, H 3.84, N 21.05; Found: C 38.44, H 3.59, N 21.33.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Synthesis of Cd4[PR43]2[BDC]2Cl4⋅7H2O (1)

A mixture of CdCl2⋅8H2O (16.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), [PR43]2+⋅2[NO3]- (80 mg, 0.05 mmol), H2BDC (8.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), and 4 mL of H2O/DMF (3:1) was stirred for 30 min, and then transferred and sealed in a 18 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which is heated at 100 °C for 72 h. Block colorless crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained, washed with distilled water, and dried in air. Yield: 40.6% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C120H142Cd4Cl8N56O39. (%): C 38.68, H 3.84, N 21.05; Found: C 38.44, H 3.59, N 21.33.

elements.content: 2 was synthesized by a procedure similar to that was used for 1 with 120 °C for 48 h. Yield: 42% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C68H84Cd2Cl2N28O28. (%): C 40.09, H 4.16, N 19.25; Found: C 40.24, H 3.93, N 19.01.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Cd2[PR43][BDC]2Cl2⋅8H2O (2)

 2 was synthesized by a procedure similar to that was used for 1 with 120 °C for 48 h. Yield: 42% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C68H84Cd2Cl2N28O28. (%): C 40.09, H 4.16, N 19.25; Found: C 40.24, H 3.93, N 19.01.

elements.content: 3 was synthesized by a procedure similar to that was used for 2 with H2BPDC (0.1 mmol, 24.2 mg) instead of H2BDC. Yield: 44% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C82H86Cd3Cl2N28O30. (%): C 41.88, H 3.69, N 16.88; Found: C 43.10, H 3.42, N 16.97.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Cd3[PR43][BPDC]2[COO]2Cl2⋅6H2O (3)

 3 was synthesized by a procedure similar to that was used for 2 with H2BPDC (0.1 mmol, 24.2 mg) instead of H2BDC. Yield: 44% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C82H86Cd3Cl2N28O30. (%): C 41.88, H 3.69, N 16.88; Found: C 43.10, H 3.42, N 16.97.

elements.content: 4 was synthesized by a procedure similar to that was used for 3 with 140 °C. Yield: 26% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C146H164Cd3Cl4N56O49 (%): C 44.21, H 4.17, N 19.78; Found: C 44.07, H 4.32, N 19.55.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Cd3[PR43]2[BPDC]3Cl4⋅10H2O (4)

 4 was synthesized by a procedure similar to that was used for 3 with 140 °C. Yield: 26% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C146H164Cd3Cl4N56O49 (%): C 44.21, H 4.17, N 19.78; Found: C 44.07, H 4.32, N 19.55.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that 1 crystallized in triclinic, space group P1̅. A typical asymmetric unit contains two Cd2+ ions, one pseudorotaxanes [PR43], four chloride atoms, one BDC ligand and five lattice water molecules. Both Cd2+ ions are six-coordinated geometry of distorted octahedron by three chloride atoms (Cd–Cl 2.5092(2)–2.5617(17) Å), two carboxylate oxygen atoms (Cd–O 2.311(5)–2.426(5) Å), and one nitrogen atom from [PR43] (Cd–N 2.317(5)–2.424(5) Å) (a). The Cd–Cl, Cd–O, and Cd–N distances fall in the normal range of the bond lengths reported previously. A close inspection of the structure reveals two Cd2+ ions are bridged by two chloride atoms to form a binuclear cadmium cluster. The Cd–Cd distance is 3.888(5) Å. The adjacent binuclear {Cd2Cl4O4} clusters are linked by BDC ligands and form infinite chains along the [4 1 −4] direction. Furthermore, these chains are interconnected by [PR43]­s along [4 −9 −6] and [−1 0 1] directions to furnish a 3D metal–organic rotaxane framework (c) (cluster-to-cluster distances: 13.47 and 13.41 Å). Topological analysis identified the architecture in 1 as a uninodal four-connected dia network (d). The fact that only half amount of the organic linkers are [PR43] in one diamondoid cage, which makes the framework spacious and allows another identical framework to interpenetrate the first one (e and Figure S1, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that 1 crystallized in triclinic, space group P1̅. A typical asymmetric unit contains two Cd2+ ions, one pseudorotaxanes [PR43], four chloride atoms, one BDC ligand and five lattice water molecules. Both Cd2+ ions are six-coordinated geometry of distorted octahedron by three chloride atoms (Cd-Cl 2.5092(2)-2.5617(17) Å), two carboxylate oxygen atoms (Cd-O 2.311(5)-2.426(5) Å), and one nitrogen atom from [PR43] (Cd-N 2.317(5)-2.424(5) Å) (a). The Cd-Cl, Cd-O, and Cd-N distances fall in the normal range of the bond lengths reported previously. A close inspection of the structure reveals two Cd2+ ions are bridged by two chloride atoms to form a binuclear cadmium cluster. The Cd-Cd distance is 3.888(5) Å. The adjacent binuclear {Cd2Cl4O4} clusters are linked by BDC ligands and form infinite chains along the [4 1 -4] direction. Furthermore, these chains are interconnected by [PR43]s along [4 -9 -6] and [-1 0 1] directions to furnish a 3D metal-organic rotaxane framework (c) (cluster-to-cluster distances: 13.47 and 13.41 Å). Topological analysis identified the architecture in 1 as a uninodal four-connected dia network (d). The fact that only half amount of the organic linkers are [PR43] in one diamondoid cage, which makes the framework spacious and allows another identical framework to interpenetrate the first one (e and Figure S1, Supporting Information).

elements.content: (a) The simplified repeated unit composed of [PR43], BDC, and Cd ions in 1. CB[6] molecules were omitted. The chemical view of (b) the 2D layer and (c) 3D frameworks in 1. CB[6]­s are shown only in the ac plane. (d) Chemical and schematic view of a single diamondoid cage and (e) two interpenetrated frameworks in 1. Color code: blue: N; red: O; gray: C; bright green: Cl; yellow: Cd; turquoise: BDC; blue rod: [PR43]; violet: CB[6]. Hydrogen atoms are omitted.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The simplified repeated unit composed of [PR43], BDC, and Cd ions in 1. CB[6] molecules were omitted. The chemical view of (b) the 2D layer and (c) 3D frameworks in 1. CB[6]s are shown only in the ac plane. (d) Chemical and schematic view of a single diamondoid cage and (e) two interpenetrated frameworks in 1. Color code: blue: N; red: O; gray: C; bright green: Cl; yellow: Cd; turquoise: BDC; blue rod: [PR43]; violet: CB[6]. Hydrogen atoms are omitted.

elements.content: Considering the flexibility and complexity of cucurbit[6]­uril-based pseudorotaxane in the self-assembly process of supra-architectures under hydrothermal conditions. We investigated the temperature effect on the above system and obtained 2 with different structure under different temperature. X-ray diffraction analysis illustrates that 2 crystallized in the monoclinic, space group P21/c, and Cd2+ has a six-coordinated octahedral geometry linked by two chloride atoms (Cd–Cl 2.5495(12) Å), three carboxylate oxygen atoms Cd–O 2.223(2)–2.458(3) Å, and one nitrogen atom from [PR43] (Cd–N 2.398(3) Å). To date, only one binuclear terbium cluster-based pcu MORF was reported by Kim et al. Here, 2 represents the first transition metal cluster-based MORF containing CB[6] with pcu topology (b). First, the two periodic Cd-carboxylate layers are constructed by the binuclear cadmium cluster and BDC ligands (Figure S2) with the dimension of grid 11 × 11 Å2. Then two-dimensional (2D) layers are further interconnected by pseudorotaxanes [PR43] pillars to form a 3D MORF (cluster to cluster distances: 21.155(5) Å). Because of the small pores in the architecture, there is not enough space to accommodate the other net to interpenetrate (c,d and Figure S2, Supporting Information). The structural comparison between 1 and 2 reveals that the coordination sphere of basic units in MORFs can be tuned by changing temperatures, and definitely the higher temperature 120 °C (rather than 100 °C) is advantageous to obtain non-interpenetrated MORFs with higher symmetry.
elements.clean_text: Considering the flexibility and complexity of cucurbit[6]uril-based pseudorotaxane in the self-assembly process of supra-architectures under hydrothermal conditions. We investigated the temperature effect on the above system and obtained 2 with different structure under different temperature. X-ray diffraction analysis illustrates that 2 crystallized in the monoclinic, space group P21/c, and Cd2+ has a six-coordinated octahedral geometry linked by two chloride atoms (Cd-Cl 2.5495(12) Å), three carboxylate oxygen atoms Cd-O 2.223(2)-2.458(3) Å, and one nitrogen atom from [PR43] (Cd-N 2.398(3) Å). To date, only one binuclear terbium cluster-based pcu MORF was reported by Kim et al. Here, 2 represents the first transition metal cluster-based MORF containing CB[6] with pcu topology (b). First, the two periodic Cd-carboxylate layers are constructed by the binuclear cadmium cluster and BDC ligands (Figure S2) with the dimension of grid 11 × 11 Å2. Then two-dimensional (2D) layers are further interconnected by pseudorotaxanes [PR43] pillars to form a 3D MORF (cluster to cluster distances: 21.155(5) Å). Because of the small pores in the architecture, there is not enough space to accommodate the other net to interpenetrate (c,d and Figure S2, Supporting Information). The structural comparison between 1 and 2 reveals that the coordination sphere of basic units in MORFs can be tuned by changing temperatures, and definitely the higher temperature 120 °C (rather than 100 °C) is advantageous to obtain non-interpenetrated MORFs with higher symmetry.

(c) The schematic and (d) topological illustration of the 3D pillared frameworks in 2. Color code: blue: N; red: O; gray: C; yellow: Cd; bright green: Cl; turquoise: BDC; blue rod: [PR43]2+; violet: CB[6]. Hydrogen atoms are omitted.

(c) The schematic and (d) topological illustration of the 3D pillared frameworks in 2. elements.content: Encouraged by the above system, when the longer auxiliary ligands like BPDC instead of BDC was used to react with [PR43] and cadmium chloride heated at 120 °C for 3 days, as expected, colorless block crystals of 3 featuring 3D pcu MORFs were well obtained. X-ray diffraction analysis illustrated that basic building unit of the framework consists two types of cadmiums (Cd1 and Cd2) ions, one BPDC anions and half of [PR43] (a). Cd1 is six-coordinated in a distorted octahedron fashion by two bridging oxygen atoms from two methanoic acid which is obtained by the decomposition of DMF (Cd–O 2.32(3) Å) and four oxygen atoms from four chelating BPDC­(Cd–O 2.224(3)–2.31(3) Å). Cd2 is also six-coordinated with octahedral geometry bridged by one nitrogen atom from [PR43] (Cd–N 2.35(3) Å), two oxygen atoms from two BPDC anions (Cd–O 2.22(3)–2.26(3) Å), two oxygen atoms from a methanoic acid (Cd–O 2.36(3)–2.53(6) Å), and one chloride atom (Cd–Cl 2.498(12) Å) (Figure S3, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: Encouraged by the above system, when the longer auxiliary ligands like BPDC instead of BDC was used to react with [PR43] and cadmium chloride heated at 120 °C for 3 days, as expected, colorless block crystals of 3 featuring 3D pcu MORFs were well obtained. X-ray diffraction analysis illustrated that basic building unit of the framework consists two types of cadmiums (Cd1 and Cd2) ions, one BPDC anions and half of [PR43] (a). Cd1 is six-coordinated in a distorted octahedron fashion by two bridging oxygen atoms from two methanoic acid which is obtained by the decomposition of DMF (Cd-O 2.32(3) Å) and four oxygen atoms from four chelating BPDC(Cd-O 2.224(3)-2.31(3) Å). Cd2 is also six-coordinated with octahedral geometry bridged by one nitrogen atom from [PR43] (Cd-N 2.35(3) Å), two oxygen atoms from two BPDC anions (Cd-O 2.22(3)-2.26(3) Å), two oxygen atoms from a methanoic acid (Cd-O 2.36(3)-2.53(6) Å), and one chloride atom (Cd-Cl 2.498(12) Å) (Figure S3, Supporting Information).

Hydrogen atoms are omitted (b) ball-and-stick and schematic representations of 3 containing H2BPDC linkers, showing a portion one of the pcu frameworks. (c) Ball-and-stick representation of the 2-fold interpenetrated frameworks in 3. Inset: each CB[6] resides in the grid from another framework. (d) Topological views of 2-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks in compound 3. Color code: blue: N; red: O; gray: C; yellow: Cd; green: Cl ; turquoise: BPDC; blue rod: [PR43]2+; violet: CB[6].

elements.content: As shown in b, two Cd2 atoms are linked with Cd1 atom, located on the symmetric center [1 0 1], by the carboxylic group of bpdc ligand, and forming a trinuclear cadmium cluster. The adjacent {Cd3} SBUs are linked from bpdc ligands to propagate a 2D grid layer parallel with bc plane. The 2D layers are further extended to a 3D coordination framework by the [PR43] as pillared ligands (cluster to cluster distances: 24.047(5) Å). Because of the utility of the longer auxiliary ligand, the large openings of void space in this 3D structure allow another identical framework to interpenetrate forming a 2-fold interpenetrated architecture (c,d). It is interesting that CB[6] of [PR43] might have played a template role in the formation of the architecture as each CB[6] resided in the grid of another pcu framework (c). Note that the six-connected nodes in 2 (formed by binuclear cadmium cluster) and 3 (formed by trinuclear cadmium cluster) are different with the classical Zn4O13 node in MOF-5 and the paddle wheel Cu2O8 node in HKUST; it is remarkable that pcu MORFs could still be obtained in a highly controlled manner.
elements.clean_text: As shown in b, two Cd2 atoms are linked with Cd1 atom, located on the symmetric center [1 0 1], by the carboxylic group of bpdc ligand, and forming a trinuclear cadmium cluster. The adjacent {Cd3} SBUs are linked from bpdc ligands to propagate a 2D grid layer parallel with bc plane. The 2D layers are further extended to a 3D coordination framework by the [PR43] as pillared ligands (cluster to cluster distances: 24.047(5) Å). Because of the utility of the longer auxiliary ligand, the large openings of void space in this 3D structure allow another identical framework to interpenetrate forming a 2-fold interpenetrated architecture (c,d). It is interesting that CB[6] of [PR43] might have played a template role in the formation of the architecture as each CB[6] resided in the grid of another pcu framework (c). Note that the six-connected nodes in 2 (formed by binuclear cadmium cluster) and 3 (formed by trinuclear cadmium cluster) are different with the classical Zn4O13 node in MOF-5 and the paddle wheel Cu2O8 node in HKUST; it is remarkable that pcu MORFs could still be obtained in a highly controlled manner.

elements.content: Inspired by the above systems, we managed to obtain 4 under similar condition, but the temperature is changed from 120 to 140 °C. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction illustrates that 4 crystallizes in the triclinic, space group P1̅. It is noteworthy that three types of cadmiums (Cd1, Cd2, and Cd3) exist in the 2D framework. Cd1 is coordinated in distorted octahedron geometry with two nitrogen atoms from two separate [PR43] linkers (Cd–N 2.351(5)–2.387(5) Å) and two oxygen atoms from two BPDC anions occupying the equatorial positions (Cd–O 2.212(4)–2.284(4) Å), while the remaining axial positions are filled by a chloride atom (Cd–Cl 2.5418(16) Å) and a single aqua molecule (Cd–O 2.536(5) Å). Cd2 is coordinated to three oxygen atoms from two BPDC anions (Cd–O 2.225(6)–2.466(4) Å), two aqua molecules­(Cd–O 2.434(5)–2.457(5) Å), and a chloride atom (Cd–Cl 2.4316(18) Å) to form a distorted octahedron, whereas Cd3 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two BPDC anions (Cd–O 2.253(6)–2.387(8) Å) and two chlorine anions­(Cd–Cl 2.4755(16)–2.535(2) Å) in distorted octahedron geometry (a). The structure of 4 is a 2D grid layer constructed by Cd atoms, bpdc, and [PR43] ligands. The interesting feature of the layer is that the cadmium ion linked by BPDC ligands in an alternative manner (Cd1-BPDC-Cd2-BPDC-Cd3-BPDC), while only Cd1 atoms act as a four connected node linked by [PR43] and bpdc ligands forming classic sqf net, Cd2 and Cd3 atoms only as two connected nodes linked by BPDC ligands. So there are large grids (about 19.8 × 44.3 Å2) in this layer, which is rare in coordination networks (b). The neighboring layers stacked along the [0 1 0] direction in a paralleled way. We noticed that the large 1D channels in the 3D supramolecular network are filled by the no-coordinated pseudorotaxanes [PR43]­s, which probably stabilized the architecture by efficient C–H···π interactions (2.7662(4) Å) between no-coordinated [PR43]­s and the [PR43]­s from adjacent layers (Figure S4, Supporting Information). The comparison of structures between 3 and 4 also illustrated that the reaction temperature has a significant effect on the self-assembly process of MORFs.
elements.clean_text: Inspired by the above systems, we managed to obtain 4 under similar condition, but the temperature is changed from 120 to 140 °C. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction illustrates that 4 crystallizes in the triclinic, space group P1̅. It is noteworthy that three types of cadmiums (Cd1, Cd2, and Cd3) exist in the 2D framework. Cd1 is coordinated in distorted octahedron geometry with two nitrogen atoms from two separate [PR43] linkers (Cd-N 2.351(5)-2.387(5) Å) and two oxygen atoms from two BPDC anions occupying the equatorial positions (Cd-O 2.212(4)-2.284(4) Å), while the remaining axial positions are filled by a chloride atom (Cd-Cl 2.5418(16) Å) and a single aqua molecule (Cd-O 2.536(5) Å). Cd2 is coordinated to three oxygen atoms from two BPDC anions (Cd-O 2.225(6)-2.466(4) Å), two aqua molecules(Cd-O 2.434(5)-2.457(5) Å), and a chloride atom (Cd-Cl 2.4316(18) Å) to form a distorted octahedron, whereas Cd3 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two BPDC anions (Cd-O 2.253(6)-2.387(8) Å) and two chlorine anions(Cd-Cl 2.4755(16)-2.535(2) Å) in distorted octahedron geometry (a). The structure of 4 is a 2D grid layer constructed by Cd atoms, bpdc, and [PR43] ligands. The interesting feature of the layer is that the cadmium ion linked by BPDC ligands in an alternative manner (Cd1-BPDC-Cd2-BPDC-Cd3-BPDC), while only Cd1 atoms act as a four connected node linked by [PR43] and bpdc ligands forming classic sqf net, Cd2 and Cd3 atoms only as two connected nodes linked by BPDC ligands. So there are large grids (about 19.8 × 44.3 Å2) in this layer, which is rare in coordination networks (b). The neighboring layers stacked along the [0 1 0] direction in a paralleled way. We noticed that the large 1D channels in the 3D supramolecular network are filled by the no-coordinated pseudorotaxanes [PR43]s, which probably stabilized the architecture by efficient C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions (2.7662(4) Å) between no-coordinated [PR43]s and the [PR43]s from adjacent layers (Figure S4, Supporting Information). The comparison of structures between 3 and 4 also illustrated that the reaction temperature has a significant effect on the self-assembly process of MORFs.

elements.content: (a) Chemical view of basic building blocks in 4. (b) The chemical view of 2D framework in 4. Color code: blue: N; red: O; gray: C; yellow: Cd; green: Cl. Hydrogen atoms are omitted.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Chemical view of basic building blocks in 4. (b) The chemical view of 2D framework in 4. Color code: blue: N; red: O; gray: C; yellow: Cd; green: Cl. Hydrogen atoms are omitted.

elements.content: The purity of the as-synthesized MORFs 1–4 was confirmed by the agreements between simulated and experimental X-ray power diffraction (XRPD) patterns (Figures S5–S9 Supporting Information). TGA were performed from 50 to 800 °C to investigate the thermal stability of MORFs 1–4 as well as the determination of water molecules present in each compound (Figures S10–S13, Supporting Information). 1 and 3 showed the first step of weight losses before around 250 °C, which corresponded to the loss of water molecules (7 water molecules for 1, calcd: 3.38; found: 3.21%; 6 water molecules for 3, calcd: 4.59%; found: 4.24%) and further rapid weight losses of 1 and 3 could be observed at temperatures (around 390 for 1, 345 °C for 3) due to the decomposition of organic components. The TGA curves of 2 exhibited continuous weight losses between 50 and 325 °C, corresponding to the release of free and coordinated water molecules (8 water molecules for 2, calcd: 7.07%; found: 6.95%). The following further weight losses (in the range from 325 to 800 °C) are attributable to the decomposition of the organic components in 2. The TGA data of 4 reveal that the first weight loss was around 250 °C, which corresponded to the loss of free water molecules (10 water molecules for 4, calcd: 4.54%; found: 4.52%). The decomposition of the organic framework began to take place at 370 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Power X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) and Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA)

The purity of the as-synthesized MORFs 1-4 was confirmed by the agreements between simulated and experimental X-ray power diffraction (XRPD) patterns (Figures S5-S9 Supporting Information). TGA were performed from 50 to 800 °C to investigate the thermal stability of MORFs 1-4 as well as the determination of water molecules present in each compound (Figures S10-S13, Supporting Information). 1 and 3 showed the first step of weight losses before around 250 °C, which corresponded to the loss of water molecules (7 water molecules for 1, calcd: 3.38; found: 3.21%; 6 water molecules for 3, calcd: 4.59%; found: 4.24%) and further rapid weight losses of 1 and 3 could be observed at temperatures (around 390 for 1, 345 °C for 3) due to the decomposition of organic components. The TGA curves of 2 exhibited continuous weight losses between 50 and 325 °C, corresponding to the release of free and coordinated water molecules (8 water molecules for 2, calcd: 7.07%; found: 6.95%). The following further weight losses (in the range from 325 to 800 °C) are attributable to the decomposition of the organic components in 2. The TGA data of 4 reveal that the first weight loss was around 250 °C, which corresponded to the loss of free water molecules (10 water molecules for 4, calcd: 4.54%; found: 4.52%). The decomposition of the organic framework began to take place at 370 °C.

elements.content: The fluoresence emission spectra of the H2BDC and H2BPDC were measured at room temperature (Figure S14, Supporting Information) and the wavelengths of the emission maxima and excitation are listed in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Behaviors and Sensing Properties

The fluoresence emission spectra of the H2BDC and H2BPDC were measured at room temperature (Figure S14, Supporting Information) and the wavelengths of the emission maxima and excitation are listed in Table S1.

elements.content: The emission spectra of 1–4 in powder form were investigated at room temperature and are also displayed in Table S1. The photoluminescence emission spectra of MORFs 1–4 have broadband peaks with maxima at 417, 422, 448, and 411 nm, under certain excitation maximum respectively (Figure S14, Supporting Information). Compared with that of related carboxylate ligands, emission spectra of 1 are slightly red-shifted 32 nm, which may be ascribed to the cooperative effects of intraligand emission and the intermolecular interactions (such as π···π stacking and hydrogen bonding) between the molecules in the solid state. A small red-shift (37 nm) is discernible in the absorption maxium of 2, attributable to the cooperative effects of intraligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). 3 shows a broad emission peak between 340 and 600 nm with the emission maximum at 448 nm, which is also slight red-shifted (38 nm) and may be also originated from LMCT. 4 almost has the same peak with maxima at 411 nm as the carboxylate ligand that 4 contains which suggests that pseudorotaxanes [PR43]­s do not show obvious contributions to fluorescence emission of 4. The fluorescence behavior of polymers is closely associated with metal ions and ligands. So, MORFs 1–3 may be applied as candidates for potential photoactive material.
elements.clean_text: The emission spectra of 1-4 in powder form were investigated at room temperature and are also displayed in Table S1. The photoluminescence emission spectra of MORFs 1-4 have broadband peaks with maxima at 417, 422, 448, and 411 nm, under certain excitation maximum respectively (Figure S14, Supporting Information). Compared with that of related carboxylate ligands, emission spectra of 1 are slightly red-shifted 32 nm, which may be ascribed to the cooperative effects of intraligand emission and the intermolecular interactions (such as π⋅⋅⋅π stacking and hydrogen bonding) between the molecules in the solid state. A small red-shift (37 nm) is discernible in the absorption maxium of 2, attributable to the cooperative effects of intraligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). 3 shows a broad emission peak between 340 and 600 nm with the emission maximum at 448 nm, which is also slight red-shifted (38 nm) and may be also originated from LMCT. 4 almost has the same peak with maxima at 411 nm as the carboxylate ligand that 4 contains which suggests that pseudorotaxanes [PR43]s do not show obvious contributions to fluorescence emission of 4. The fluorescence behavior of polymers is closely associated with metal ions and ligands. So, MORFs 1-3 may be applied as candidates for potential photoactive material.

elements.content: To explore the potential application of 1 for the sensing of metal ions, the powders of 1 were immersed in an aqueous solution of M­(NO3) x (M = Cd2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Zn2+, Ni2+, or Cu2+). As shown in , the PL intensities of 1 are rest with the metal ion–aqueous solutions, particularly in the cases of the Cd­(NO3)2 and Fe­(NO3)3 solutions. The Cd2+ ions increase the emission intensities, and Fe3+ has a quenching effect. Moreover, the effect of different concentrations of Cd2+ and Fe3+ was also investigated. The luminescence intensity increased quickly with the concentration of Cd­(NO3)2 increased (Figure S15, Supporting Information). In constrast, the luminescence intensity decreased proportionally to the concentration of Fe3+ (Figure S16, Supporting Information). The interesting enhancing effect of Cd2+ and the quenching effect of Fe3+ on 1 provide a prospect for further sensing material studies.
elements.clean_text: To explore the potential application of 1 for the sensing of metal ions, the powders of 1 were immersed in an aqueous solution of M(NO3) x  (M = Cd2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Zn2+, Ni2+, or Cu2+). As shown in , the PL intensities of 1 are rest with the metal ion-aqueous solutions, particularly in the cases of the Cd(NO3)2 and Fe(NO3)3 solutions. The Cd2+ ions increase the emission intensities, and Fe3+ has a quenching effect. Moreover, the effect of different concentrations of Cd2+ and Fe3+ was also investigated. The luminescence intensity increased quickly with the concentration of Cd(NO3)2 increased (Figure S15, Supporting Information). In constrast, the luminescence intensity decreased proportionally to the concentration of Fe3+ (Figure S16, Supporting Information). The interesting enhancing effect of Cd2+ and the quenching effect of Fe3+ on 1 provide a prospect for further sensing material studies.

elements.content: Comparisons of the luminescence intensities of incorporating different metal ions in 10 mM aqueous solutions of M­(NO3) x (M = Cd2+, Zn2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Ni2+ or Fe2+) and the metal-ion free 1 (excited at 310 nm).
elements.clean_text: 5  Comparisons of the luminescence intensities of incorporating different metal ions in 10 mM aqueous solutions of M(NO3) x  (M = Cd2+, Zn2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Ni2+ or Fe2+) and the metal-ion free 1 (excited at 310 nm).

elements.content: Meanwhile, the luminescence properties of 1 in different solvent emulsions were investigated. The solvents used were trichloromethane (CHCl3), ether, ethanol (EtOH), water, ethyl acetate, acetonitrile, methanol, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), acetone, and tetrahydrofuran (THF). As shown in , the PL spectra are largely rest on the solvent molecules, particularly in the case of CHCl3 and acetone, which show the most markedly enhancing and quenching effects, respectively. Such solvent-dependent luminescence properties are interesting for the sensing of CHCl3 and acetone solvents. When 1 was dispersed in CHCl3 solution, the luminescence intensity of the emulsion gradually decreased with acetone added (). Interestingly, the fluorescence decrease was nearly proportional to the acetone concentration. The quenching efficient of acetone in this system can be attributed to the interaction of the solute and the solvent, which leads to the electron transfer from the excited 1 to electron-deficient acetone.
elements.clean_text: Meanwhile, the luminescence properties of 1 in different solvent emulsions were investigated. The solvents used were trichloromethane (CHCl3), ether, ethanol (EtOH), water, ethyl acetate, acetonitrile, methanol, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), acetone, and tetrahydrofuran (THF). As shown in , the PL spectra are largely rest on the solvent molecules, particularly in the case of CHCl3 and acetone, which show the most markedly enhancing and quenching effects, respectively. Such solvent-dependent luminescence properties are interesting for the sensing of CHCl3 and acetone solvents. When 1 was dispersed in CHCl3 solution, the luminescence intensity of the emulsion gradually decreased with acetone added (). Interestingly, the fluorescence decrease was nearly proportional to the acetone concentration. The quenching efficient of acetone in this system can be attributed to the interaction of the solute and the solvent, which leads to the electron transfer from the excited 1 to electron-deficient acetone.

elements.content: Comparisons of the luminescence intensities of compound 1 CHCl3 emulsion in the presence of various content of acetone (excited at 310 nm).

elements.content: Four high-dimensional metal–organic rotaxane frameworks were fabricated by combining CB[6]-based pseudorotaxanes [PR43]2+·2­[NO3]−, rigid carboxylate ligands (H2BDC, H2BPDC), and cadmium ions. Comparing the structures of 1, 2, 3, and 4, we discovered that the coordination sphere of metal clusters in MORFs can be tuned by changing temperatures and the length of auxiliary ligands. For 1 and 2, the high temperature was advantageous to obtain non-interpenetratedpcu MORF when the BDC ligand is applied, while, compared with 2 and 3, which were synthesized under same temperature, the trinuclear cluster SBU was formed with the longer BPDC ligand, and a 2-fold intepenetrated pcu network was constructed owing to the longer ligand. It can be envisioned that more functional porous materials would be designed and obtained by adjusting the temperature and the length and geometry of auxiliary ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Four high-dimensional metal-organic rotaxane frameworks were fabricated by combining CB[6]-based pseudorotaxanes [PR43]2+⋅2[NO3]-, rigid carboxylate ligands (H2BDC, H2BPDC), and cadmium ions. Comparing the structures of 1, 2, 3, and 4, we discovered that the coordination sphere of metal clusters in MORFs can be tuned by changing temperatures and the length of auxiliary ligands. For 1 and 2, the high temperature was advantageous to obtain non-interpenetratedpcu MORF when the BDC ligand is applied, while, compared with 2 and 3, which were synthesized under same temperature, the trinuclear cluster SBU was formed with the longer BPDC ligand, and a 2-fold intepenetrated pcu network was constructed owing to the longer ligand. It can be envisioned that more functional porous materials would be designed and obtained by adjusting the temperature and the length and geometry of auxiliary ligands.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of CdCl2·8H2O (16.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), [PR43]2+·2­[NO3]− (80 mg, 0.05 mmol), H2BDC (8.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), and 4 mL of H2O/DMF (3:1) was stirred for 30 min, and then transferred and sealed in a 18 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which is heated at 100 °C for 72 h. Block colorless crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained, washed with distilled water, and dried in air. Yield: 40.6% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C120H142Cd4Cl8N56O39. (%): C 38.68, H 3.84, N 21.05; Found: C 38.44, H 3.59, N 21.33.

Synthesis of Cd<sub>2</sub>[PR43]­[BDC]<sub>2</sub>Cl<sub>2</sub>­·8H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

2 was synthesized by a procedure similar to that was used for 1 with 120 °C for 48 h. Yield: 42% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C68H84Cd2Cl2N28O28. (%): C 40.09, H 4.16, N 19.25; Found: C 40.24, H 3.93, N 19.01.

Synthesis of Cd<sub>3</sub>[PR43]­[BPDC]<sub>2­</sub>[COO]<sub>2</sub>Cl<sub>2</sub>­·6H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

3 was synthesized by a procedure similar to that was used for 2 with H2BPDC (0.1 mmol, 24.2 mg) instead of H2BDC. Yield: 44% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C82H86Cd3Cl2N28O30. (%): C 41.88, H 3.69, N 16.88; Found: C 43.10, H 3.42, N 16.97.

Synthesis of Cd<sub>3</sub>[PR43]<sub>2</sub>­[BPDC]<sub>3</sub>Cl<sub>4</sub>­·10H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

4 was synthesized by a procedure similar to that was used for 3 with 140 °C. Yield: 26% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C146H164Cd3Cl4N56O49 (%): C 44.21, H 4.17, N 19.78; Found: C 44.07, H 4.32, N 19.55.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Synthesis of Cd4[PR43]2[BDC]2Cl4⋅7H2O (1)

A mixture of CdCl2⋅8H2O (16.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), [PR43]2+⋅2[NO3]- (80 mg, 0.05 mmol), H2BDC (8.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), and 4 mL of H2O/DMF (3:1) was stirred for 30 min, and then transferred and sealed in a 18 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which is heated at 100 °C for 72 h. Block colorless crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained, washed with distilled water, and dried in air. Yield: 40.6% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C120H142Cd4Cl8N56O39. (%): C 38.68, H 3.84, N 21.05; Found: C 38.44, H 3.59, N 21.33.

Synthesis of Cd2[PR43][BDC]2Cl2⋅8H2O (2)

 2 was synthesized by a procedure similar to that was used for 1 with 120 °C for 48 h. Yield: 42% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C68H84Cd2Cl2N28O28. (%): C 40.09, H 4.16, N 19.25; Found: C 40.24, H 3.93, N 19.01.

Synthesis of Cd3[PR43][BPDC]2[COO]2Cl2⋅6H2O (3)

 3 was synthesized by a procedure similar to that was used for 2 with H2BPDC (0.1 mmol, 24.2 mg) instead of H2BDC. Yield: 44% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C82H86Cd3Cl2N28O30. (%): C 41.88, H 3.69, N 16.88; Found: C 43.10, H 3.42, N 16.97.

Synthesis of Cd3[PR43]2[BPDC]3Cl4⋅10H2O (4)

 4 was synthesized by a procedure similar to that was used for 3 with 140 °C. Yield: 26% based on [PR43]. Elemental analysis calc. for C146H164Cd3Cl4N56O49 (%): C 44.21, H 4.17, N 19.78; Found: C 44.07, H 4.32, N 19.55.

Power X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) and Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA)
